description:
Aromatoleum evansii is a species of bacteria that belongs to the Betaproteobacteria class. It is a facultatively anaerobic, gram-negative, and motile bacterium. Aromatoleum evansii is capable of degrading a wide range of aromatic compounds, including benzene, toluene, and ethylbenzene, under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions.

The bacterium was first isolated from a hydrocarbon-contaminated aquifer and was named after Dr. Philip J. Evans, who made significant contributions to the understanding of anaerobic hydrocarbon degradation. Aromatoleum evansii is known to possess diverse metabolic pathways, allowing it to thrive in environments with varying oxygen levels and the presence of aromatic pollutants.

This species is of interest in the field of bioremediation, as it has the potential to be utilized in the cleanup of sites contaminated with aromatic hydrocarbons. Its ability to degrade these compounds under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions makes it a valuable tool for the treatment of a wide range of environmental pollutants.
